data.title: Dell Steels Software Biz With SonicWall
data.meta_description: Dell has acquired software security outfit SonicWall, continuing to expand its software business under the direction of former Computer Associates CEO John Swainson. SonicWall sells "unified threat management" software -- software for overseeing a wide range of security tools, from antivirus applications to virtual private networks to intrusion detection -- as well as its own firewall software.
data.text:
Dell has acquired software security outfit SonicWall, continuing to expand its software business under the direction of former CA Technologies CEO John Swainson.

"We're very pleased to have John Swainson as the leader of our software group," said Dell senior vice president of strategy Dave Johnson during a conference call with reporters on Tuesday, "and SonicWall will be a cornerstone of his software group -- from a security perspective."

SonicWall sells "unified threat management" software -- software for overseeing a wide range of security tools, from antivirus applications to virtual private networks to intrusion-detection tools -- as well as its own firewall software. The company boasts over 300,000 active customers, and it sells through a network of over 1,500 channel partners. Over the past year, the company raked in about $260 million in revenue.

"Dell is building a software portfolio focused on highly profitable and fast-growing segments," Swainson said. "SonicWell ... positions us well in a fast-growing segment of the security business, and the SonicWall team ... is a great cultural fit with Dell."

Last month, Dell purchased backup software outfit AppAssure, and its software business also spans tools it acquired with the purchase of SecureWorks, another security outfit; patch-management company Kace; data center management outfit Scalent; and Boomi, a Philadelphia outfit offering software and services for integrating a business' various back-end applications. Dell already offers security tools under the AppAssure and Kace names as well as the SecureWorks brand.

SonicWall is based in San Jose, California, not far from what Dell calls the Dell Silicon Valley Research and Development Center -- a new office that houses the former employees of Scalent, storage outfit Ocarina, and desktop management player Everdream as well as other new Silicon Valley staff.

Dell began life as a PC company, but it has since morphed into a company that seeks to tackle the entire IT landscape, from servers to storage to networking to software to services. The acquisition of SonicWall -- the latest step along that road -- is expected to close sometime in the second quarter.
